thread.title: Celebrity showdown: Mets vs. Dodgers famous fans
thread.title_full: Celebrity showdown: Mets vs. Dodgers famous fans

author: KATE FELDMAN
title: Celebrity showdown: Mets vs. Dodgers famous fans
text:
Share this URL Kathy Willens/AP Comedian Jerry Seinfeld, left, and Seinfeld show co-creator Larry David, shown here at the Mets Opening Day in April, are among celebrities that have aligned themselves with competing baseball teams. 
The Mets make their first postseason appearance since 2006 Friday night, but the players aren’t the only ones competing. 
Over the years, both the Mets and the Dodgers have compiled a long list of celebrity fans, many of whom will be out at the stadium during the upcoming series. 
Mets: Savulich, Andrew Comedian Jerry Seinfeld is probably the most famous and most vocal celebrity Mets fan. 
The man behind “Seinfeld” is one of the biggest Mets fans out there, famous or otherwise. 
He pops into his suite and the SNY booth frequently, but he’s best known for his Twitter comments. Dear @ynscspds ,You are a great baseball player. I love watching you!Do Cubans really like those Cuban sandwiches?I love them!Go #mets — Jerry Seinfeld (@JerrySeinfeld) August 6, 2015 
Jon Stewart 
The former “Daily Show” host wasn’t afraid to show his loyalty to the orange and blue on the air or around the ballpark. 
A good Mets team brought out the best in Stewart (skip to around the 8:05 minute mark). Get More: Comedy Central , Funny Videos , Funny TV Shows 
Hank Azaria 
Queens native and diehard Mets fan Hank Azaria voices more “Simpsons” characters than we can count, and he put that to use on MLB Network earlier this year. Your browser does not support iframes. 
Dylan O’Brien Paul Zimmerman/WireImage Actor Dylan O'Brien is among the youngest celebrity Mets fans. 
“Teen Wolf” star Dylan O’Brien is a self-prescribed “long suffering Mets fan,” which is a pretty apt description. 
He even convinced his writers to allow his character to be a fan of the Amazin’s. 
Fictional honorable mention: Josh Lyman on “The West Wing” 
The deputy chief of staff on “The West Wing” is known for his quirks and his mania, which of course includes the Mets. 
The season two episode “The Stackhouse Fillibuster” takes place just before spring training: 
JOSH 
I'm going to Port Saint Lucie, which may not mean anything to you, buthappens to be the spring training home of the... 
C.J. 
New York Jets. Yes, you've told me. Josh, you can watch basketball on T.V. 
JOSH 
Yes, except the New York Knicks are a basketball team, the New York Jets are a football team, and Port Saint Lucie is the spring training home of the New York... 
C.J. 
Mets! Yes. D-
